column12: Collision avoidance in fast drive mode
column13: The system shall detect the approximation of solid obstacles at critical collision areas of the system during fast drive mode (e.g. towards moving direction), e.g.  by means of a distance sensor.    When an approximation is detected, the system shall reduce the speed to OR (operating room) mode speed before an imminent collision takes place.    During normal operation (e.g. stopping without collision / approximation, emergency stop activation without collision / approximation), the system shall not create false positive collision / approximation detection information.    The functionality of the sensor shall be tested during boot and monitored during operation (e.g. checking and calibrating by regularly scanning known fixed mounted objects with differing fixed distances to the sensor).    When an error in the sensor system is detected, the system shall go to operating room speed (deactivate fast drive mode) and indicate the error to the operator.

The system sets the movement speeds according to different modes and control, see <XREF>569146</XREF>, and in order to meet the overtravel limits <XREF>562465</XREF> and to not exceed the speed limits <XREF>563486</XREF> in normal conditions.

The acceleration of motorized movements under normal conditions is defined in <XREF>569146</XREF>.   For maneuverability of the system, the set speed values are deemed to be sufficient.    The acceleration (and deceleration) is however monitored for mechanical stability <XREF>563680</XREF>.

Furthermore, fast drive mode shall only be allowed if the footswitch is disconnected.    When the system is in fast drive mode, and movements are initiated from other movement controls than from the chassis handle, the system shall apply max.    OR mode speed (set speed).
After at most 300 seconds of chassis standstill in fast drive mode, there shall be a timeout deactivating the fast drive mode automatically.

column12: Control elements protected against unintended movement or x-ray activation
column13: The control elements shall be designed in such a manner that unintended movement or x-ray activation by the operator is prevented e.g. :- Joysticks are recessed and have an additional movement triggering switch- No locking of buttons in activated position possible- For the wireless and wired remote control, no function shall be activated when the component is dropped or put reversely on a flat surface (see also 60601-1 cl.    15.   3.   1).   - At least control elements related to switching the system on/off, chassis movement initiation, brake control and x-ray release shall be recessed.   - Handle for power assisted chassis movements shall have two switches / buttons / sensors which are physically separated.   - The system shall only allow movement initiation from the handles if force is applied within 2 s timeout after the capacitive sensors are activated.   Note: In case the timeout passes by without force being applied or when trying to reinitiate a movement after a temporary stop that exceeds the timeout, the operator needs to release the handles and start a new movement.

column12: Continuous activation of movements with redundant activation paths
column13: Motorized movement shall be possible only when two redundant signals provided by two independent paths are present (continuous activation), preventing unintended movement activation.    When only one of two paths is activated, all motorized movements shall be stopped and inhibited for the respective control.   　Note: Safety architecture C + P, see <XREF>561860</XREF> and <XREF>543971</XREF>.   For design constraints for single fault safety, see <XREF>578311</XREF>.    Further note: For network interfaces cyclic retriggering (cyclic messages within e.g.  150 ms) are seen as equivalent to continuous activation.

column12: Emergency stop at every point of motorized movement activation

Points of movement activation (control locations) are:- control panel at the FD cover- wireless hand control- wired hand control- Backside of Servo-Handle Chassis The emergency stop shall be designed according to IEC 60947-5-1 and IEC 60947-5-5.     When an emergency stop is activated, all motorized movements of the system except the motorized monitor height adjustment shall be stopped (e.g. stop category 1, thereof e.g. safe stop 1 function according to 61800-5-2) and inhibited until it is deactivated again.    　Note 1: Safety architecture C + P, see <XREF>561860</XREF> and <XREF>543971</XREF>.   For design constraints for single fault safety, see <XREF>578311</XREF>.     Note 2: For behaviour regarding radiation, see <XREF>562135</XREF>.

column12: Safe power supply of protection module hardware
column13: The protection module hardware shall have a safe power supply: The over- / undervoltage protection shall be either redundantly implemented or be tested at startup.    The voltage limits shall be defined according to the guaranteed working voltages of the hardware to ensure correct functionality.    When the startup test fails or one of the over-/undervoltage protection detects an error, all motorized movements and radiation shall be inhibited.

The following general principles for designing the protective path shall be considered:- The software of the protective path shall be developed according to software safety class C (IEC 62304).   - Common causes (errors or environmental conditions that could affect C and P simultaneously) shall be considered and excluded by design:   ESD / transients (sufficient electrical isolation between P and C path signals), temperature out of specified limits, etc.    For components which are connected to the protection module, especially the integration requirements of <XREF>580888</XREF> shall be considered.     Note 1: Safe power supply of P and the mechanical mounting of the encoders have already separate requirements <XREF>578161</XREF>, <XREF>578163</XREF>,<XREF>578173</XREF>.    Note 2: For design contraints for single fault safety, see <XREF>578311</XREF>.

column12: Alternative deactivation of emergency stop - hand control
column13: There shall be an alternative safe way to deactivate an emergency stop of the wireless and the wired hand control with a deliberate action (two subsequent actions) by the operator.   For the wireless hand control: Only if the hand control connection is lost with an activated e-stop by this control: After the connection loss, an activation and deactivation must take place at another emergency stop.   For the wired hand control: Only if the wired hand control functionality is lost with an activated e-stop by this control: Unplugging the wired hand control and thereafter activating and deactivating another emergency stop.   Note 1: The single actions of unplugging the wired hand control or putting the wireless hand control in the drawer shall not deactivate the emergency stop.   If a connection is re-established and the e-stop has been released in the meanwhile at another device, the e-stop shall not be present.    If the e-stop has not been released in the meanwhile at another device, then the e-stop shall remain present until resolved.     Note 2: This is deemed to sufficiently prevent the scenario, that an e-stop is deactivated unintentionally when e.g. two operators activate their e-stops nearly simultaneously (followed by a deactivation of the second one), since it is deemed very unlikely that the sequence connection loss, and e-stop already is activated, another e-stop is activated for another purpose or unintentionally than to deactivate the e-stop in general.

column12: NGS protocol with link loss detection
column13: Use of reliable data transfer standards and protocols (i.e.  TCP/IP protocol for Ethernet-based communication) with a heartbeat and link loss detection.    Its also valid for OpenApps.   If the link loss is detected, it shall be indicated to the user and an automatic release of mouse events shall occur.

Use of reliable data transfer standards and protocols (i.e.  TCP/IP protocol for Ethernet-based communication) with a latency detection.    This means measuring the time between sending a frame till receiving this frame and in case of exceeding a configurable limit to indicate it with an audible or visual indicator.    VxFUTURE:  when using NGS in the OpenApps context, the latency detection shall be configurable specific to the app (i.e.  either deactivated or threshold value adjusted based on the Risk Managmenent of the individual partner apps).

column12: NGS protocol with update rate detection
column13: Use of reliable data transfer standards and protocols (i.e.  TCP/IP protocol for Ethernet-based communication) with a update rate detection between two frames.    In case of  exceeding a configurable time an audible or visual indication shall be done.     VxFUTURE: This can be configured individually for partner apps (either deactivated or a threshold value configured based on the respective partner app's Risk Manamagement proposal) in case of OpenApps.

For transfer of frames via NGS the data integrity of these frames shall be considered by using a check sum algorithm (e.   g CRC32).    In case of  an incorrect checksum is detected an audible or visual indication shall be done.     When NGS is used in context of OpenApps, the temporal integrity of an image series that builds on one another must also be monitored using a checksum.    Incase of a missing image or incorrect CRC, an audible or visual indication shall be available.

Introduction IEC 60601-1, cl 11.   7 and specifically ISO 10993-1 describe the general principles governing the biological evaluation of medical devices within a risk management framework, including the general categorization of devices based on the nature and duration of their contact with the body.   The range of possible chemical and biological hazards is wide and can include short-term effects such as acute toxicity, irritation to the skin, eye and mucosal surfaces, haemolysis and thrombogenicity, as well as long-term or specific toxic effects such as subchronic and chronic toxic effects, sensitization resulting in allergy, genotoxicity, carcinogenicity (tumorigenicity) and effects on reproduction or development, including teratogenicity.   Essential for the risk assessment of these hazards is to determine how critical are substances within the components and how likely it is that these substances are transferred to people to trigger a response.   Note, the following evaluation is based on <XREF>347633</XREF>, specifically the guidance for biological evaluation of medical devices in acc.    with ISO 10993-1.    Overview and classification The <XREF>276902</XREF> describes the "nature and duration of body contact" for patients and users with the system.    It is rated as a non-contacting medical device, because there is no direct contact between patient and the system required to fulfill the intended use.    However, system contact is possible within the following situations:1.    "Intended" short term (only seconds or minutes) contact (predominantly with the hand) with intact skin of qualified personnel (Manufacturing, Installation, Service, etc.   ) or the clinical personal at system control covers or control elements.   2.    Unintended (e.g.  touched accidentally during a procedure) short term (only seconds or minutes) contact at the C-arm area with intact or non-intact skin of the patient.    The CIOS systems are out of scope of ISO 10993-1 with the following rationales: Rationale and details for system operators System operators get in contact with user interfaces such as handles, control elements, PC-accessories or covers.    These users are qualified manufacturing, installation, service or clinical personnel which are expected to have intact skin at their hands or are wearing gloves during work.    Also the contact duration is very short-term considering the duration of contact categories in ISO 10993-1.    Thus no detailed biological evaluation is needed for these components.    However, in general it shall be shown that the materials of these components are in common use for other consumer products with a similar nature of contact, see <XREF>597019</XREF>.   Furthermore, all the components are fulfilling applicable regulations (RoHS, REACH, etc.   ) which are restricting the use of substances of high concerns in medical devices and products.    Rationale and details for patients The mobile C-arm systems are rated as non-contacting medical devices for patients.    No direct or indirect contact is required to fulfill the intended use of the system.    However, short-time contact is possible between patient skin (intact and in rate cases non-intact) and the C-arm area (C-Arm, detector cover and monobloc cover).    Also it cannot be fully excluded that there might be a leakage of bodily fluids of the patient onto the above described system area.    Therefore, this area specifically needs to be covered by sterile or sterilizable covers, see <XREF>562240</XREF>, effectively protecting the system and patient.    Since there is no reasonably assumable contact between the patient and other parts of the device no further biological evaluation is needed.
